verses.text: A lazy man is compared to a worthless stone, and everyone mocks his sluggishness.
verses.comment: The image of a worthless stone highlights the biblical condemnation of sloth (cf. Prov. 6:6–11). Diligence is seen as a virtue, reflecting the value of active participation in the life of faith.

verses.text: A lazy son brings dishonor to his father, and people mock the foolish offspring.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the importance of honoring one's parents by living wisely. Parental authority and respect for family are consistent themes throughout Scripture.

verses.text: A fool's disgrace is more burdensome than his father's loss, for folly is an ongoing shame.
verses.comment: Foolishness causes lasting pain, affecting family and community. The continuation of folly can have deep spiritual consequences.

verses.text: Death is preferable to the life of a fool, for his existence accomplishes nothing.
verses.comment: Strong language sharply contrasts wise and foolish living. The text implies that spiritual death begins in persistent folly.

verses.text: Spending time with a mindless man is like life in a dark cave.
verses.comment: Folly equates to spiritual blindness, a theme that recurs throughout the wisdom tradition.

verses.text: Mocking a fool is the same as waking a sleeper from deep slumber.
verses.comment: Correcting folly is difficult—often fruitless—yet Christians are called to exercise patience and strive for the salvation of souls.

verses.text: Explaining wisdom to a fool is like speaking to someone who is asleep; at the end he will say, 'What was it?'
verses.comment: Wisdom requires an open heart. The verse suggests the necessity of grace and receptivity, key themes in spiritual growth.

verses.text: Weep less for the dead, since he has found rest, but weep bitterly for a fool, for his life is worse than death.
verses.comment: The concept of 'rest' prefigures Christian teaching on the hope of resurrection. Persistent sin is worse than physical death, echoing the tragic consequences of spiritual separation from God.

verses.text: Mourning for the dead lasts seven days, but mourning for a fool or the ungodly lasts a lifetime.
verses.comment: Jewish custom prescribed mourning periods, but spiritual death leaves a longer mark. The liturgy's concern for the souls of the departed echoes this focus on the destiny of the soul.

verses.text: Do not speak much with a foolish man, and do not associate with him. Guard yourself from trouble and avoid injury.
verses.comment: The advice against fellowship with fools is found throughout wisdom literature. Keeping company with the wise fosters virtue.

verses.text: He will stain you by association, and you will inherit his disgrace.
verses.comment: Bad company corrupts good morals. The spiritual life demands careful discernment concerning friendship and influence.

verses.text: Avoid gazing at a fool, and do not sit with him among elders. Do not listen to his words.
verses.comment: Wisdom is to be found among the righteous, and the importance of good counsel is stressed here.

verses.text: Protect yourself from him, so that you may not become like him. Stay far from his mischief, and you will find rest and peace.
verses.comment: Sanctification often involves separation from those committed to evil, reinforcing the biblical call to holiness.

verses.text: A blow to the body makes most people feel, but a fool only learns through much suffering.
verses.comment: The discipline required to teach wisdom recalls the fatherly correction central to the spiritual tradition.

verses.text: As a dog always returns to its vomit, so a fool repeats his foolishness.
verses.comment: Scripture draws a memorable parallel, comparing persistent folly to unclean habits. The New Testament echoes this in warning against apostasy.

verses.text: Talking with a fool is like talking to someone fast asleep; at the end he asks, 'What was it?'
verses.comment: The verse repeats earlier imagery to stress the difficulty of imparting wisdom to the unteachable.

verses.text: While you mourn a fool, his soul lacks hope; but the soul of the dead finds rest.
verses.comment: There is greater spiritual emptiness in the fool than in the dead, foreshadowing Christian ideas of spiritual resurrection and the ultimate rest found in Christ.

verses.text: Throwing stones at a grave shows disrespect for the dead, and insulting a fool is useless.
verses.comment: Respect for the dead was an important tradition; the analogy warns against wasting effort on hardened folly.

verses.text: Sand and salt and a lump of iron are easier to bear than a foolish person.
verses.comment: The cumbersome nature of a fool outweighs even heavy burdens, emphasizing the strain folly creates in community life.

verses.text: A wooden beam bound together is not easily broken, but the heart of a fool is stubborn and hard to change.
verses.comment: Unlike physical objects that can be altered, spiritual stubbornness in folly resists correction, underscoring the need for confirmed conversion.

verses.text: One who corrects a foolish man is like one who glues fractured pottery—it will break again.
verses.comment: Foolishness is deeply ingrained and often recurs. Spiritual transformation requires internal change by grace.

verses.text: Mocking a foolish person aggravates his wounds, just as a captive suffers repeated blows.
verses.comment: Harsh correction may do more harm than good. Mercy and patience are emphasized in biblical teaching.

verses.text: If you protect your friend from misfortune, loyalty will remain; but if you reveal his secrets, you will lose trust forever.
verses.comment: Guarding your friend's reputation is a mark of true friendship. Discretion and trust are highly valued—see also David and Jonathan's friendship (1 Sam. 20).

verses.text: Love your neighbor and be faithful to him; but if you betray his trust, do not follow him.
verses.comment: Loving one's neighbor reflects Christ's commandment and the spiritual dimension of charity and forgiveness.

verses.text: Like a lost friend, if you reveal secrets, you cannot regain his trust.
verses.comment: Once betrayed, trust is hard to restore. Scripture upholds reconciliation but warns of consequences for repeated offense.

verses.text: Even if you get back a friend's trust through many prayers, a wound once opened may still bleed.
verses.comment: The power of prayer in reconciliation is implied here; still, healing takes time and effort. The verse hints at the value of persistence in both prayer and forgiveness, a pattern found in Jesus' teaching.

verses.text: Anyone who throws stones at birds chases them away, and anyone who insults a friend breaks the relationship.
verses.comment: Relationships flourish with gentleness and are broken by carelessness or malice. Maintaining harmony reflects a spiritual call to unity, echoing the prayers for peace in the community of believers.
